Award.AwardTitle: CSR: Student Travel Support for SIGMETRICS 2016

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The ACM SIGMETRICS / IFIP PERFORMANCE 2016 conference will be held at Congress Center, Antibes Juan-les-Pins, France, June 14-18, 2016. SIGMETRICS brings together professionals from academic and industrial backgrounds in what has become a premier forum for discussing the development and application of state-of-the-art, broadly applicable analytic, simulation, and measurement-based performance evaluation techniques. The SIGMETRICS conference presents innovative, exciting work related to all aspects of performance, including speed and scalability as well as reliability, availability, and manageability of systems. Highly original ideas, new approaches, and/or ground breaking results are expected and this year offers a poster session for the presentation of promising preliminary work

Travel support will make possible the participation of students who would otherwise be unable to attend. Particular attention is paid to directing support towards under-represented groups. The support will provide students who attend with the opportunity to interact with a diverse group of mentors and peers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to offer travel grants to help graduate students attend ACM SIGMETRICS 2016, the premiere conference on performance modeling and measurement of computer systems and networks. This conference was held in Juan-les-pines, France during June 14-18 2016 with the PI serving as the student travel grants chair. The funds for this project were used to offer travel grants to 13 graduate students. 

A key intellectual merit of the project consisted of the ideas the funded students brought to the conference through their paper presentations (a majority of students were co-authors on a paper at the conference or one of its satellite workshops). These students were also actively involved in a variety of informal engagements with other participants of the conference during workshops and breaks. Such interactions - both with experienced researchers and other graduate students from around the world - helped the funded students to assess their own research according to very high standards. 

The broader impact of the grant consisted of exposing these young and budding researchers to top-notch research in performance evaluation. In terms of promoting diversity, the funded students represented 9 different universities from different parts of the US. Among them were 2 women students. Finally, the students were in different stages of their PhDs.
